summary: An analytical video comparing techniques from catch wrestling and Judo, highlighting similarities and differences. The video draws on historical footage and modern examples to illustrate the evolution and effectiveness of throws.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white scene of a boxing match in a ring, with a referee and spectators in the background. The focus then shifts to a judo match, where two men in white uniforms perform a throw, with other judo practitioners observing. The scene transitions back to the boxing ring, where the two boxers continue their match, with the referee closely monitoring. The video then shows a book cover titled "Wrestling Jiu Jitsu" by Charles Lederham, featuring an embossed image of two wrestlers. The cover is dark with intricate designs and a library label in the top left corner. The video concludes with a close-up of the book cover, emphasizing its title and design.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing the topic of old-school catch wrestling, particularly its throws, mentioning common discussions around groundwork and rivalry with Judo's ground techniques. He announces a focus on throws, referencing a book with the title "The Art the Science of Wrestling and the Art of Jujitsu" as the main source of information. He clarifies that he will be focusing on the wrestling part of the book.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a book titled "Wrestling and Jiu Jitsu" by Charles Lederer, featuring an embossed illustration of two wrestlers on its cover. The scene transitions to a black-and-white photograph of two men engaged in a wrestling move, with one man kneeling and the other standing over him, both wearing shorts and wrestling shoes. The text "Inside Leg and Arm Drop" appears at the bottom of the image, accompanied by a detailed description of the move. The next frame shows the same photograph with the text "Inside Leg and Arm Drop (Continued)" at the bottom, indicating a continuation of the move. The video then shifts to a modern setting where two individuals in white martial arts uniforms with black belts are practicing a grappling technique on a mat. The background is a plain blue wall, and the individuals are focused on executing the move, demonstrating the evolution of wrestling techniques from historical to contemporary practices.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio starts with a male speaker beginning to describe a technique, mentioning terms like "inside leg and arm drop." He speaks in a relatively calm tone, noting there is nothing particularly unique to discuss, citing similarities to "Katamata" and the "fireman's carry." He mentions commonality with folk-style wrestling and other disciplines, adding that even the one-knee block is present. He then mentions checking out a "Kukokan" example. The speaker describes someone pulling "Kusushi" and utilizing the one-knee position, throwing the opponent over the shoulder with the hand. He reiterates that this is not especially remarkable and can be found in many martial arts styles.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two individuals dressed in white martial arts uniforms, engaged in a grappling match on a mat. One person is on the ground, while the other is in a dominant position, applying a hold. The scene then transitions to a black and white photograph of two wrestlers in a grappling position, with one wrestler applying a back, head, and waist lock to the other. The photograph includes text at the bottom, which reads "Back, Head and Waist Lock (Continued)" and provides instructions on how to execute the move. The wrestlers are wearing wrestling attire, and the background is plain, emphasizing the technique being demonstrated. The video maintains a focus on the instructional aspect of martial arts and wrestling techniques, showcasing both live-action and photographic examples.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker discusses an interesting technique involving a back heel, arm wrapping, and driving backwards. He connects it to "Osoto Otoshi" or "Osoto Gari", noting that it resembles Scottish backhold wrestling and catch wrestling. He mentions that while there's a Judo approach, the entry differs and references the Pedro footage, courtesy of Fighting Films, available in the description.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a judo match between two competitors, one in a white gi and the other in a blue gi, on a mat with a dark background featuring the "FF" logo. The competitors engage in a series of grappling techniques, with the person in the blue gi attempting to control and maneuver the person in the white gi. The person in the white gi, identified as "A. MCDONALD USA" on the back of their gi, counters and executes a throw, taking the person in the blue gi to the ground. The match continues with both competitors demonstrating various holds and techniques, including a leg hold. The video transitions to a historical black-and-white photograph of two men in a similar grappling position, with the caption "Back Hold and Leg Hold (Continued)" indicating a continuation of the technique being demonstrated. The video captures the intensity and skill involved in judo, highlighting the physicality and strategic nature of the sport.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker describing a judo move by Kayla Harrison, detailing the specific maneuvers and differences in technique compared to a standard throw. He expresses curiosity about how a catch wrestler might approach the move. The speech includes technical language, with a clear tone. Subsequently, the speaker describes another wrestling move, noting the occurrence of a leg grab and a leg reap simultaneously.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two men engaged in a wrestling move, with one man holding the other's leg and arm. The text "Back Heel and Leg Hold (Continued)" is visible at the bottom of the image, indicating that this is a continuation of a wrestling technique demonstration. The scene then transitions to a judo dojo where two men, one in a white gi and the other in a black gi, are practicing a judo technique called "Soto-ashi-dori-ouchi-gari," which is labeled as "Outer Leg Hold Inner Reap." The men are shown executing the move, with one man lifting the other off the ground. The video then shifts to a different dojo where two men in white gis are practicing a technique called "Ōuchi-gari," as indicated by the Japanese text "大内刈り" (Ōuchi-gari) displayed on the screen. The men are seen grappling and executing the throw. Throughout the video, the focus is on demonstrating various martial arts techniques, with the practitioners wearing traditional martial arts attire and the settings being dojo environments.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker discussing catch wrestling and striking disciplines, mentioning moves like "O Uchi Gari." His tone is informative. He also discusses Judo and terminology like "Soto Ashidori" and "Torimasu," citing "efficient Judo" as a source. He mentions the use of grabbing in MMA and Karate to perform techniques like "Kouchi" or "Deashiharai," or simply to pummel opponents.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two individuals dressed in white martial arts uniforms with black belts, engaging in a grappling technique on a tatami mat. They are in a close embrace, with one person attempting a leg sweep while the other tries to maintain balance. The background features wooden panels, suggesting a dojo setting. The scene transitions to a black-and-white photograph of two men in wrestling attire, demonstrating a double leg takedown technique. The man on the left is standing, while the man on the right is bent over, with his legs wrapped around the standing man's legs. The text at the bottom of the photograph reads "Double Leg Dive" and provides instructions on executing the move. The video then returns to the martial arts demonstration, where the two individuals continue their grappling, with one successfully executing a throw, causing the other to fall to the mat. The video concludes with the two individuals on the ground, one on top of the other, showcasing the effectiveness of the grappling technique.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by mentioning "grabbing the leg" during a strike and tearing the other one, noting its commonality. He asserts that the human body is the same worldwide, making conclusions easy. His interest lies in the entry, but old books don't offer much assistance due to the time and printing limitations.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two men engaged in a wrestling move, with one man bent over and the other standing behind him, holding his leg. The caption reads "Double Leg Dive" and provides instructions on how to perform the move. The scene then transitions to a modern-day setting where two men in white martial arts uniforms with black belts are practicing a similar move on a mat with a blue background. The men demonstrate the technique by grappling and executing a takedown, showcasing the evolution of the wrestling move from the historical photograph to the contemporary practice.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing a double leg takedown technique. His tone is analytical and slightly critical as he questions the effectiveness of certain elements of the technique. He expresses uncertainty, saying he doesn't want to be wrong, but questions the optimality of the approach. The speaker then describes the technique as a "Morote-gari", explaining that you don't have to pick up. He describes a dive in "kind of like a tackle", emphasizing the importance of going low and not bending the back like a wrestler. He ends the segment with a question regarding finishing the takedown due to its inefficiency and proneness to attacks.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a black and white photograph of two muscular men engaged in a wrestling stance, with one man's left hand gripping the other's right wrist. Both men are wearing black shorts and wrestling shoes, and their facial expressions are focused and intense. The background is plain and dark, emphasizing the subjects. The text at the bottom of the image reads "Standing Double Wrist Lock With Back Heel" and provides instructions on how to perform the move, emphasizing the importance of keeping the opponent's left hand close to the body and using the right hand to apply pressure. The overall atmosphere is instructional, highlighting the physicality and technique of wrestling.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker, with a focused tone, begins by explaining a move from a double wristlock grip, noting it's an "underrated grip" for takedowns and common in grappling, especially for "sumi gaeshi." He cites examples of martial artists, naming "Shoori Hamada, Uta Abe, and Masahiko Kimura." The speaker mentions plans to demonstrate examples later before transitioning to the "this one," likely referring to a specific technique.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two muscular men engaged in a wrestling stance, with one man's left hand holding the other's right wrist, demonstrating a technique. The men are wearing black shorts and wrestling shoes, and the background is plain, focusing attention on their form and technique. The text at the bottom of the image reads "Standing Double Wrist Lock With Back Heel," indicating the specific wrestling move being demonstrated. The scene then transitions to a color photograph of two individuals in a judo match, one wearing a white gi and the other in a blue gi, with the blue gi competitor executing a throw. The background shows spectators and photographers capturing the event, emphasizing the competitive atmosphere. The video then shifts to a playful scene of two dogs, one white and one brown, wrestling on a plain floor, showcasing their playful interaction. The sequence highlights the contrast between the intense physicality of human wrestling and judo, and the lightheartedness of canine play.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker brainstorming possibilities, mentioning a "legless fireman" and techniques like "I kido's Kokyunage." His tone is enthusiastic as he suggests various moves, such as "whip it downward" and "Yoko Wakare." He then transitions to describing a specific grip and its advantages in taking someone's balance, followed by references to "Utabe" and Masahiko Kimura, describing how they use a similar technique. The male speaker notes that  "Bushart" is "just tapping endlessly." The male speaker's tone is enthusiastic and descriptive.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two individuals dressed in white martial arts uniforms engaging in a grappling match on a mat. One person, wearing a black belt, executes a throw, taking the other to the ground. They continue to grapple, with the person in the black belt maintaining control. The scene transitions to a black-and-white boxing match in a ring, with two boxers in the center, surrounded by a crowd. The referee is visible, overseeing the match. The boxers engage in a series of punches and defensive maneuvers, with the crowd watching intently. The video captures the intensity and focus of both the martial arts and boxing matches, highlighting the physicality and skill involved in each sport.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the efficiency of a grip technique, elaborating on its use in submissions and maintaining a pin. He speaks in an informative tone, promising to demonstrate a simple example. The speaker describes a wrestling hold called Ushiro Kesa Gatame and its effectiveness in maintaining control. He emphasizes the grip's efficiency for both submissions and takedowns.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a black and white scene of two men dressed in traditional martial arts uniforms, standing in a dimly lit room. They face each other, bowing their heads in respect before engaging in a series of martial arts moves. The men demonstrate various techniques, including grappling and throws, while a group of onlookers, also dressed in martial arts attire, observe from the background. The atmosphere is focused and disciplined, with the men displaying skill and precision in their movements. The video captures the essence of martial arts training, emphasizing respect, technique, and the importance of observation and learning from others.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Russian tie-ins and grip techniques, admitting uncertainty about the subject and stating that no-gi isn't his area of expertise. He then invites listeners to comment and mentions that a book link will be available in the description below. The clip features only one speaker, with a casual, conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a group of men dressed in traditional martial arts uniforms, kneeling on the ground in a dimly lit room. One man stands out as he performs a martial arts move, lifting another man off the ground and throwing him to the floor. The scene transitions to a wrestling match in a ring, where two wrestlers are engaged in a physical struggle. The wrestler in the foreground is attempting to lift and throw his opponent, who is resisting. The audience watches intently as the match unfolds, with a referee standing nearby, observing the action closely. The atmosphere is tense and focused, with the audience's attention fixed on the wrestlers' movements. The video captures the intensity and skill involved in both martial arts and wrestling, showcasing the physical prowess and technique of the participants.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker expressing gratitude for the links, books, and material he received from friends, which he intends to discuss. He also requests support on Patreon for exclusive content. The speaker sounds thankful and concludes by saying "only this was Chatty and thank you for listening".
